awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Undergraduate Research Groups in the CSU Alliance for PUMP: Preparing Undergraduates through Mentoring toward PhDs
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on increasing the participation of underrepresented students in PhD programs in the mathematical sciences. These students include undergraduates currently at a California State University (CSU) which are ethnic minorities, first-generation college, or financially disadvantaged. This will be accomplished by a CSU Alliance including all 23 campuses, which provides a robust recruitment process, training for faculty on how to be a strong mentor, and frequent assessment. Students are equipped with the tools to be successful in doctoral programs through high-quality, personalized activities. PUMP has already had tremendous success on southern CSU campuses and is now being extended to include northern campuses as well.

The activities for this project include (a) an orientation workshop for faculty geared to maximize the success of mentoring students from underrepresented groups; (b) at least one year of undergraduate research projects for junior and senior math majors; and (c) a PUMP symposium where the undergraduates will present talks on their research. The PUMP undergraduate research group (URG) is structured so that students master the mathematical content while developing the ability to go from general course work to independent work and research. The program requires that topics for the URGs, while accessible to students, make meaningful contributions to the mathematical sciences, allowing the faculty from institutions with limited research opportunities to keep current and active in their fields. This project shall contribute to increasing the quantity, quality, and diversity of the mathematical sciences workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the PUMP project include (1) forming a new state-wide alliance among all 23 campuses of the California State University (CSU) system, which extends the program PUMP: Preparing Undergraduates through Mentoring toward PhDs, (2) building a community of mentors that will work on creating welcoming and inclusive departments and on institutionalizing the values of mentoring, and (3) increasing the number of students from the historically underrepresented racial and ethnic groups who enter doctoral programs in the mathematical sciences. The main activity is the academic year URGs (Undergraduate Research Groups) composed of a faculty advisor and two undergraduate math majors investigating open problems. 

In AY 2020-21, there were 19 URGs representing a good mixture of northern (8 URGs) and southern (11 URGs) campuses which were critical for the forming of a new PUMP Alliance across all CSUs. Moreover, the students are members of groups historically underrepresented in math and/or first-generation college populations. In the past, PUMP has had tremendous success with its students entering Ph.D. programs, and continuing this trend with the new alliance and network of mentors is a major priority. In AY 2022-23, supplemental funding was used for four additional URGs at Fresno State, CSU Los Angeles, and CSU Northridge formed with two to three students each. San Jose State University, the lead institution, has one year before ending the grant activity and it will be used to analyze new data about the outcomes of the PUMP project.

The intellectual merit lies in the engagement with open problems from a range of sub-disciplines in the mathematical sciences. Supporting faculty research and best practices in mentoring undergraduate research, particularly among diverse populations, is key to success. The topics represented include Fractal Geometry and Analysis, Quantum Mechanics in Simple Matrix Form, Algebraic Topology, Applied Mathematics, Data Analysis and Predictive Modeling, Math Biology, Graph Theory, and Mathematics Education. 

The broader impacts include increasing community in the mathematics discipline beyond the baccalaureate through pathways to graduate school at California State Universities. Moreover, enriching the community through faculty mentoring meetings that impact the culture around diversity. Of 36 student participants, six have reported being accepted into Ph.D. programs in the mathematical sciences, and an additional 14 plan to apply as they advance to their senior year. The collaboration with the University of Utah Pre-REU demonstrates the impact beyond the program.


Last Modified: 11/18/2022
Modified by: Cynthia V Flores
